questions.question_text: What term describes the structured system of communication, consisting of grammar and vocabulary, that humans use to convey meaning through spoken, signed, or written forms?
What type of writing system uses a standard set of symbols called letters, where each letter largely corresponds to an individual speech sound (phoneme) in a spoken language?
What class of speech sounds is produced with an open vocal tract, without any stricture, and typically forms the nucleus or center of a syllable?
What class of speech sounds is articulated with complete or partial closure of the vocal tract, as opposed to the open configuration used for vowels?
What term describes a variety of a language distinguished by differences in phonology, morphology, syntax, and vocabulary, spoken by a particular regional or social group?
In sociolinguistics, what term refers to a distinctive way of pronouncing a language that is associated with a particular country, region, social class, or ethnic group?
What is the process of communicating the meaning of a source-language text by producing an equivalent text in a target language, as distinct from oral interpreting?
What type of language uses the visual-manual modality, including manual articulations and non-manual markers, and is a full natural language with its own grammar and lexicon?
What is the general term for any conventional method of visually representing a language using symbols, encompassing alphabets, syllabaries, logographies, and abjads?
What term describes the ability to use two or more languages, a condition that research suggests characterizes more than half of the world's population?

What is the basic unit of organization within spoken language that typically consists of a vowel nucleus with optional surrounding consonants, and serves as the building block for the rhythm of speech?
What term describes a group of languages that are related to each other through descent from a common ancestral language, known as a proto-language?
What term refers to the first language that a person learns from birth or within the critical period, also called a native language or mother tongue?
In linguistics, what is the smallest unit of sound in a language that can distinguish one word from another, such as the difference between /p/ and /b/ in 'pat' versus 'bat'?
Which subfield of linguistics studies the internal structure of words, including how morphemes such as prefixes, roots, and suffixes combine to form complex words?
Which subfield of linguistics examines how language varies and changes across different social groups, regions, and cultural contexts, combining dialectology with the social sciences?
Which subfield of linguistics, also known as diachronic linguistics, studies how and why languages change over time, including sound shifts, grammatical changes, and language divergence?

What standardized system of phonetic notation, created by the International Phonetic Association in the late 19th century, is used by linguists worldwide to transcribe the sounds of any spoken language?
What branch of linguistics studies the origin and historical development of words, tracing how their forms and meanings have changed over time across languages?

What term describes the process by which humans, particularly children, gain the ability to perceive, produce, and use language to communicate, typically progressing from babbling to full sentences in the first few years of life?

In the study of lexical borrowing, what term describes a foreign expression whose meaning is translated morpheme-by-morpheme into the receiving language rather than adopting the donor language's phonetic form?

options.A: A calque, also called a loan translation
options.B: A neologism, also called a coined formation
options.C: A cognate, also called a genetic inheritance
options.D: A loanblend, also called a hybrid borrowing

questions.question_text: What is the fundamental linguistic criterion that differentiates a creole language from a pidgin?

options.A: A creole has native speakers who acquired it as a first language, while a pidgin does not
options.B: A creole possesses complex grammatical morphology, while a pidgin has no systematic grammar
options.C: A creole derives its vocabulary from a single source language, while a pidgin draws from several
options.D: A creole has a standardized written form and orthography, while a pidgin is exclusively oral

questions.question_text: In prosody, how does intonation primarily differ from lexical tone as a suprasegmental feature of speech?

options.A: Intonation marks grammatical case and agreement relations, while tone signals verb tense and aspect
options.B: Intonation operates at the phrase or sentence level, while tone distinguishes meaning at the word or syllable level
options.C: Intonation is found exclusively in Indo-European languages, while tone occurs only in Sino-Tibetan languages
options.D: Intonation conveys meaning through variations in loudness, while tone conveys meaning through variations in pitch

questions.question_text: What distinguishes psycholinguistics from theoretical linguistics as an academic discipline?

options.A: Psycholinguistics analyzes the formal grammatical rules governing sentence structure across languages
options.B: Psycholinguistics examines how social and cultural factors influence language variation among communities
options.C: Psycholinguistics studies the mental mechanisms underlying language acquisition, production, and comprehension
options.D: Psycholinguistics focuses on documenting endangered languages and preserving global linguistic diversity

questions.question_text: In UNESCO's Language Vitality and Endangerment framework, what endangerment level describes a language that children no longer learn as their mother tongue in the home?
In pragmatics, what term coined by H. Paul Grice describes the meaning a speaker conveys beyond the literal content of an utterance, inferred from conversational context and cooperative principles?
When two sounds in a language occur in the same phonetic environments and substituting one for the other changes word meaning, what distributional relationship do they exhibit?

options.A: Morphophonemic alternation, indicating they are conditioned by morphological context
options.B: Free variation, indicating they are interchangeable without meaning change
options.C: Complementary distribution, indicating they are allophones of one phoneme
options.D: Contrastive distribution, indicating they are separate phonemes

questions.question_text: In Mandarin Chinese, the syllable 'ma' can mean 'mother,' 'hemp,' 'horse,' or 'scold' depending on its pitch contour. What linguistic feature produces these distinctions?

options.A: Contrastive stress, where syllable emphasis distinguishes word meaning at the phrase level
options.B: Lexical tone, where pitch contour distinguishes word meaning at the syllable level
options.C: Vowel quality shift, where tongue position alters the vowel to change word meaning
options.D: Sentence intonation, where pitch pattern indicates the speaker's attitude or intent

questions.question_text: A phonologist finds that speakers of Language X perceive [s] and [ʃ] as the same sound. What evidence would prove these are actually distinct phonemes?

options.A: A demonstration that both [s] and [ʃ] can occur at the beginning of words
options.B: A spectrographic analysis showing that [s] and [ʃ] have different acoustic properties
options.C: An articulatory description showing that [s] and [ʃ] use different tongue positions
options.D: A minimal pair showing that substituting [s] for [ʃ] changes word meaning

questions.question_text: In English, the aspirated [pʰ] in 'pin' and unaspirated [p] in 'spin' are perceived as the same sound. What phonological relationship describes these two phones?

options.A: They are allophones of the phoneme /p/ in complementary distribution
options.B: They are free variants of the phoneme /p/ selected randomly by speakers
options.C: They are distinct phonemes that happen to share the same orthographic representation
options.D: They are coarticulated variants of the phoneme /p/ conditioned by speaker dialect

questions.question_text: In linguistic typology, which basic word order is the most common among the world's languages, found in languages such as Japanese, Turkish, and Korean?
In morphological typology, which type of language constructs words by stringing together clearly separable morphemes, each carrying a single grammatical meaning, as seen in Turkish and Swahili?
Which systematic sound change, first noted by Rasmus Rask and formalized by Jacob Grimm, describes the shift of Proto-Indo-European voiceless stops to voiceless fricatives in Proto-Germanic?

options.A: Grimm's Law, also called the First Germanic Consonant Shift
options.B: Verner's Law, also called the Second Germanic Consonant Shift
options.C: The Great Vowel Shift of Middle English pronunciation
options.D: Grassmann's Law, also called the Indo-European Aspiration Dissimilation

questions.question_text: In historical linguistics, what is the primary goal of the comparative method when applied to cognate forms across related languages?

options.A: To determine which modern language most closely resembles the original ancestor
options.B: To reconstruct the features of their common ancestor, known as the proto-language
options.C: To identify universal grammatical rules shared by all human languages
options.D: To classify languages by their morphological type, such as isolating or fusional

questions.question_text: In sociolinguistics, what distinguishes intrasentential code-switching from intersentential code-switching among bilingual speakers?

options.A: Intrasentential switching involves borrowing single words, while intersentential switching involves translating idioms
options.B: Intrasentential switching occurs within a single sentence, while intersentential switching occurs at sentence boundaries
options.C: Intrasentential switching uses formal registers only, while intersentential switching uses informal registers
options.D: Intrasentential switching occurs only in writing, while intersentential switching occurs only in speech

questions.question_text: Which argument does Noam Chomsky use to support his theory of Universal Grammar, claiming that children acquire language despite insufficient input from their environment?

options.B: The poverty of the stimulus argument

questions.question_text: The critical period hypothesis, popularized by Eric Lenneberg in 1967, proposes that native-like language acquisition must occur before what developmental milestone?

options.A: The age of three, when babbling transitions to first words
options.B: The onset of puberty, when brain lateralization becomes fixed
options.C: The age of twenty-five, when prefrontal cortex development completes
options.D: The first year of life, when auditory processing pathways form

questions.question_text: The Sapir-Whorf hypothesis exists in two forms. What does the strong version (linguistic determinism) claim, in contrast to the weak version (linguistic relativity)?

options.A: That language fully determines thought and perception, rather than merely influencing them
options.B: That children acquire language innately, rather than learning it from environmental input
options.C: That all languages share a universal deep structure, rather than differing only at the surface
options.D: That writing systems shape cognition more than spoken language, rather than equally

questions.question_text: In distinctive feature theory, Chomsky and Halle's 1968 work 'The Sound Pattern of English' formalized features as binary values. What does the feature [+voice] specifically indicate about a speech sound?

options.A: That the velum is lowered allowing airflow through the nasal cavity
options.B: That vibration of the vocal folds occurs during articulation of the segment
options.C: That the airstream is released with a burst of aspiration after closure
options.D: That the tongue body is raised toward the palate during production

questions.question_text: In Goldsmith's autosegmental phonology framework, what formal constraint prevents association lines linking tonal and segmental tiers from crossing each other?

options.A: The sonority sequencing principle, which governs syllable-internal segment order
options.B: The obligatory contour principle, which bans adjacent identical autosegments
options.C: The strict layer hypothesis, which requires proper prosodic nesting
options.D: The no-crossing condition, a well-formedness constraint on multi-tiered representations

questions.question_text: In metrical phonology, how is linguistic stress represented, unlike earlier generative models that treated it as a feature of individual segments?

options.A: As an autosegmental tier of binary tonal features linked to individual mora units by association lines
options.B: As a numerical value assigned to each vowel segment through cyclic rule application in linear derivations
options.C: As a fixed acoustic intensity threshold measured in decibels and assigned to each syllable nucleus
options.D: As a relational property between hierarchically organized constituents labeled strong or weak in tree structures

questions.question_text: In the prosodic hierarchy, what principle formulated by Selkirk and Nespor & Vogel prohibits a prosodic constituent from dominating units that skip a level?
In Optimality Theory, what happens when a winning output candidate violates a lower-ranked constraint that a rival candidate satisfies?

options.A: The violation triggers a repair rule that modifies the winner to satisfy the lower-ranked constraint
options.B: The winner is disqualified and the rival candidate is automatically promoted to the optimal output
options.C: Both candidates are eliminated and the generator must produce a new set of candidate forms
options.D: The winner is still selected because it better satisfies a higher-ranked constraint than the rival does

questions.question_text: Grammaticalization involves content words becoming function words over time. Which concurrent process describes the progressive loss of a word's original lexical meaning during this change?
In ergative-absolutive languages, which grammatical roles receive the same case marking, in contrast to nominative-accusative alignment?

options.A: The transitive subject and the transitive object both receive ergative case marking
options.B: The intransitive subject and the transitive object both receive absolutive case
options.C: The transitive object and the indirect object both receive the same dative case marking
options.D: The intransitive subject and the transitive subject both receive nominative case marking

questions.question_text: In phonological opacity, what type of rule interaction occurs when a later rule creates the environment for an earlier rule, but the earlier rule has already failed to apply?

options.A: Counterbleeding, resulting in overapplication opacity on the surface
options.B: Transparent feeding, resulting in full application of both rules
options.C: Counterfeeding, resulting in underapplication opacity on the surface
options.D: Mutual bleeding, resulting in both rules being vacuously satisfied

questions.question_text: In articulatory phonetics, the consonant [n] is classified as a voiced alveolar nasal. What does the 'alveolar' label specifically refer to?

options.A: The degree of oral cavity opening that determines the resonance quality of the nasal airflow
options.B: The manner of articulation involving complete airflow blockage followed by a sudden release burst
options.C: The laryngeal setting in which the vocal folds vibrate during the entire duration of the sound
options.D: The place of articulation where the tongue tip contacts the bony ridge behind the upper teeth

questions.question_text: William Wang's lexical diffusion hypothesis proposes that sound change spreads gradually across the vocabulary. How does this contrast with the Neogrammarian position?

options.A: Neogrammarians proposed that sound change is triggered by contact between unrelated language families
options.B: Neogrammarians claimed sound change applies uniformly to all applicable words at once, not word by word
options.C: Neogrammarians argued sound change originates in written language and later transfers into spoken forms
options.D: Neogrammarians held that sound change occurs only in unstressed syllables and never in stressed ones

questions.question_text: Laryngeal realism proposes that aspirating languages like English and true voice languages like French differ in their underlying laryngeal feature. What feature do aspirating languages use?

options.A: [constricted glottis] rather than [nasal] to represent the contrast between obstruent series
options.B: [stiff vocal folds] rather than [slack vocal folds] to represent voicing in all consonants
options.C: [high pitch] rather than [low pitch] to represent the tonal distinction in stop consonants
options.D: [spread glottis] rather than [voice] to represent the contrast between obstruent series

questions.question_text: In language contact studies, what term describes the linguistic influence left by a subordinate language that is eventually replaced by a dominant one in a community?
